properties.Name: Camp Wood
properties.Synopsis: Camp Wood, also known as Camp Dubois, was the expedition's home base for five months. Clark established the original campsite and served as camp director while Lewis procured supplies for the long, arduous journey ahead. The expedition departed Camp Wood on May 14th, 1804, in a keelboat and two pirogues, beginning their long venture up the Missouri River.
properties.Secondary Source: Ripley Hitchcock. The Lewis and Clark Expedition (Boston: Ginn & Company, 1905), p. 21.

properties.Name: Cupboard Creek
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark named their first geographical feature: Cupboard Creek.
properties.Secondary Source: Rogers, Ann. Lewis and Clark in Missouri.  Columbia: University of Missouri Press, 2002.

properties.Name: Council Bluffs
properties.Synopsis: In present day Nebraska a bronze set of statues stand to commemorate the historic meeting between the Lewis & Clark Expedition and the tribes of the Otos and the Missouris. The meeting occurred at the site of Council Bluffs. The Oto tribe was part of the Southern Sioux tribes and they resided along the Missouri River. Their livelihood was based mostly on hunting the buffalo but they also farmed. Their huts were oven-shaped, earth-covered houses grouped into towns. Upon meeting them, Lewis remarked "Those two parts of nations, Ottos and Missouries, now residing together is about 250 men". However, due to smallpox, this number represented only a fraction of what the population had once been. The disease that had wiped out much of the Native Americans had severely depleted their numbers. The meeting at Council Bluffs involved several chief members of the tribes and the Lewis & Clark Expedition. During the council, the Native Americans were told they were the "children" of a new "great father" who would provide them with trade and protection in place of their unreliable commerce with the French and the Spanish. It was a speech Lewis would deliver to numerous tribes throughout the journey.

properties.Name: Punishment of Moses Reed
properties.Synopsis: On night of the expedition, Moses Reed had told the captains he had left his knife at the previous night's campsite, and set out as if to retrieve it. However, soon the members of the expedition learned that Reed had fled, and moreover, La Liberte, one of the engagés, had apparently left with him. Four men were sent to bring him back and he was apprehended after a 12-day pursuit. He should have received a total of 828 strokes, but instead was dismissed from the Expedition and sent home.
properties.Secondary Source: Brandt, Anthony. "Decision Point: An Unexpected Fork in the Missouri River Presented a Monumental Challenge to the Leadership of Lewis and Clark.(Meriwether Lewis and William Clark)." American History 48, no. 5 (2013): 32-40.

properties.Name: Sergeant Charles Floyd Dies
properties.Synopsis: For an expedition sent out into unknown territory, the risk of death would seem to be remarkably high. However, only one man died on the journey across the great West. Charles Floyd died on August 20th, 1804, not from any bear attack, drowning, or act of violence. His death was the result of appendicitis. However, this disease was not known to the people of this time period, so Floyd would have died even if he had resided back in the East. His body is buried on a bluff near present-day Sioux City.
properties.Secondary Source: Floyd, Charles, and Holmberg, James J. Exploring with Lewis and Clark : The 1804 Journal of Charles Floyd. Norman, Okla.: University of Oklahoma Press, 2004.

properties.Name: First Buffalo
properties.Synopsis:
Private Joseph Field killed the expedition's first buffalo.  Hunting was central to the Corps' survival and identity. 
 They hunted not just to acquire food, but as part of a friendly competition for bragging rights.  They also shot specimens to study and to practice their aim.  Members of the expedition did not have the same spiritual relationship to animals as the Plains Indians among whom they traveled.
properties.Secondary Source: Slaughter, Thomas P.  Exploring Lewis and Clark: Reflections on Men and Wilderness.  New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2003, p. 134-159.

properties.Name: First sighting of prairie dogs
properties.Secondary Source: Cutright.  Lewis and Clark: Pioneering Naturalists

properties.Name: Teton Confrontation
properties.Synopsis: One of the most important diplomatic missions of Lewis & Clark assigned by Jefferson was to negotiate with the Sioux tribes. On September 23rd, 1804 Lewis & Clark were setting up camp when three Teton Sioux boys came across the river. Knowing the risk, but also knowing that this was their chance, the expedition invited the chiefs to a meeting. The next few days the expedition and a larger number of Indians held council on a sandbar in the Bad River. The expeditions went through their usual charades of presenting western medicine and military technologies to the Native Americans but things began to grow hostile. Eventually tensions erupted leaving the expedition holding guns, surrounded by fierce warriors with their bows strung. Wary of violence Clark and one of the chiefs, Black Buffalo, engaged in a tense conversation.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988.

properties.Name: Council with Teton Lakota Indians
properties.Synopsis: Several days after the Teton Council things continued to take a turn for the worst. The expedition left, but as they were heading out to set up camp they were offered Sioux women, a gesture by the tribe in order to show some acknowledgements to the expedition. However, after spending some three days with the Teton Sioux they experienced trouble after their boat was damaged. In a series of events, the crisis with the boat and the arrival of Brulé warriors, led to another standoff with the Teton Sioux. However, neither Lewis & Clark nor Black Buffalo wished for this to end in violence, and they were able to diffuse the situation. Lewis & Clark left, unable to finish negotiations with the Sioux who remained an obstacle for trade in the Upper Missouri for some time.

properties.Name: Encounter with Arikaras
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark tried hard to build an alliance with agricultural Plains peoples like the Arikara and Mandans, trying to set them against the nomadic Sioux, as part of their effort to build a new American trade system in the Plains. The Arikara and Mandans were a semi-nomadic people who relied heavily on agriculture. An early European botanist praised the Arikara women as excellent cultivators. He had not seen finer crops anywhere in America. They were known for their cultivation of corn.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James.  Lewis and Clark Among the Indians, Nebraska, 1984, p. 49.

properties.Name: Newman's Insubordination
properties.Synopsis: Private Newman reached a breaking point on October 13th, 1804. He was charged with showing signs of a "highly criminal and mutinous" nature. He was accused of trying to incite a mutiny against the expedition and destroy the principles towards which they had been working. He was charged with 75 lashes to the back and discharged from the expedition to be sent home. However, since they were in route through the wilderness, he continued to travel with them to Fort Mandan. He performed hard labor and tried to redeem himself in the eyes of Lewis & Clark, but was sent back east with the return party in April 1805.
properties.Secondary Source: http://lewisandclarktrail.com/courtmartial.htm

properties.Name: First Encounter with Mandan and Hidatsa Indigenous Peoples
properties.Synopsis: The expedition passed through an abandoned Hidatsa village and noted a lack of game along the river, indicating the presence of indigenous peoples. While resting on the banks of the Missouri River, they encountered a hunting party of Mandan tribal members and subsequently three Mandan lodges constructed on an island. Lewis and Clark camped on the north side of the river; they visited with five Mandan, including the Chief, and smoked together in an act of diplomacy. The Mandan people would become integral to Lewis and Clark’s westward journey, thus establishing a peaceful relationship with this tribe was a salient historical moment.

properties.Name: Fort Mandan
properties.Synopsis: The expedition party constructed a winter fort in modern-day McLean County, North Dakota, where they gathered supplies and conducted diplomatic business with local indigenous peoples. Lewis and Clark encountered French fur trader Toussaint Charbonneau and Sacagawea here for the first time. They also acquired crucial information about western terrain from the Mandan and Hidatsa native groups.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, p.

properties.Name: First Encounter with Toussaint Charbonneau and Sacajawea
properties.Synopsis: On this day, Lewis & Clark encounter a man by the name of Toussaint Charbonneau, a meeting that would change the fate of the expedition. Toussaint Charbonneau was a French-Canadian trapper, who had lived in the region for 8 years. This first meeting brought Lewis & Clark their first interpreter, another French-Canadian trader by the name of Rene Jussome. Clark notes in his diary that this meeting was accompanied by two Indian women, one of whom was most likely Sacajawea, the woman whose name is almost as famous as Lewis & Clark, and without whose presence, the expedition may not have succeeded. She was a slave who had been sold to him from her original tribe, but because she accompanied the expedition she was able to return home during the journey.
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: Setting a Bad Example
properties.Synopsis: At Fort Mandan, Thomas Howard decided to scale the wall of the fort. Upon seeing this, one of the Native Americans in the area tried to mimic him and climb the wall as well. Howard was tried in court for his action and sentenced to 50 lashes. This seems like an extreme punishment for something as simple as scaling a wall, but the people of the expedition were worried that if the Native Americans knew that the wall could be scaled that they would be in danger.
properties.Secondary Source: http://lewisandclarktrail.com/courtmartial.htm

properties.Name: Sacajawea Gives Birth
properties.Synopsis: After the winter of 1804-1805, the expedition had picked up several new members. Charbonneau and his wife Sacajawea, were among them. Sacajawea had left Fort Mandan pregnant, and on February 11th, after a long and difficult labor, gave birth to her first son. The boy was named Jean Baptiste Charbonneau and became the youngest member of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: Lewis' Newfoundland Dog
properties.Synopsis: No expedition is complete without the companionship of a large, black, furry water dog causing trouble everywhere he goes. Lewis was accompanied on his trip by a large Newfoundland dog, weighing 140 pounds, named Seaman. On the journey he alternated between bravery and foolishness. He was big enough to kill an antelope swimming in the river and haul it in. Yet when he first met a harmless-looking beaver, he was badly bitten.
properties.Journal Entries: On April 26, 1805 Ordway wrote: “Capt Lewises dog Scannon took after a flock of goats and caught one in the river.”
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: Lewis Kills His First Grizzly
properties.Synopsis: Lewis killed the first grizzly bear of the expedition. It was the largest bear they had encountered throughout their journey—according to Lewis, the bear weighed an estimated 600 pounds. Lewis and another member of the expedition fired 10 shots at it before it died. The majority of the other bears up until this point had been smaller and less threatening than this one. At the end of their trip Lewis believed that the expedition had been very lucky to not lose anyone to a grizzly bear. He wrote that "the hand of providence has been most wonderfully in our favor."
properties.Secondary Source: Furtwangler, Albert. Acts of Discovery : Visions of America in the Lewis and Clark Journals. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1993, p. 56. and LALIBERTE, ANDREA S., and WILLIAM J. RIPPLE. "Wildlife Encounters by Lewis and Clark: A Spatial Analysis of Interactions between Native Americans and Wildlife." BioScience 53, no. 10 (2003): 994-1003. doi:10.1641/0006-3568(2003)053[0994:weblac]2.0.co;2.

properties.Name: White Pudding
properties.Synopsis: Charbonneau prepared a "boudin blanc" (white pudding) from a buffalo killed by Lewis.  Finding food was one of the expedition's chief daily challenges and in the buffalo country of the Great Plains they had frequent opportunity to feast. Adequate food supplies would dwindle as the expedition entered the mountains and flirted with starvation.
properties.Secondary Source: Furtwangler, Albert. Acts of Discovery : Visions of America in the Lewis and Clark Journals, p. 97.

properties.Name: Sacajawea's River
properties.Synopsis: On May 14th, the expedition encountered yet another speed bump along their long trek home. The group had been enjoying an easy day on the water, when suddenly a gust of wind struck the boats, leaving one three hundred yards away, lying on its side in the river. Supplies began floating downstream as Cruzatte and Charbonneau tried to right the boat, but the true hero of the day was Sacajawea. While carrying her baby, she calmly fished out of the river everything that floated near her. Without her, dozens of valuables would have been lost to the river. On May 20th, Sacajawea received an official recognition of her contributions to the group and her actions on the river six days earlier.
properties.Journal Entries: “The Indian woman, to whom I ascribe equal fortitude and resolution with any person on board at the time of the accident, caught and preserved most of the light articles which were washed overboard.”
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: White Cliffs
properties.Synopsis: The expedition passed the White Cliffs of the Missouri, large sandstone formations visible from the river.

properties.Name: Marais River Intersection
properties.Synopsis: It was unclear which branch of the river was the true Missouri. Lewis and Clark sent scouting parties out in an effort to determine along which path the expedition would proceed. Sergeants and privates favored the river's north branch, but the captains decided on the north fork, which was the true Missouri.

properties.Name: Portage around the Great Falls (Great Falls, MT).
properties.Synopsis: The expedition undertook an excruciating 18-mile trek around the Great Falls of the Missouri River. Lewis set out early in the morning with an advance party, crossing level plains before ordering his four companions to separate in search of game. Thus, he was alone—according to his journals—when he came across the breathtaking Great Falls of the Missouri River. Lewis was overwhelmed by the falls' beauty, describing them as "sublime," and longing for a means more apt than a journal entry through which to convey their impressiveness. After drawing a topographical sketch, Lewis bemoaned his inability to fully express the scene. "After wrighting this imperfect description I again viewed the falls and was so much disgusted by the imperfect idea it conveyed of the scene that I determined to draw my pen across it and begin again, but then I reflected that I could not perhaps succeed better than penning the first impressions of the mind." The expedition began a grueling hike around the falls, a reminder that they were now leaving plain country and beginning an intense ascent into the Rocky Mountains.
properties.Secondary Source: Furtwangler, Albert. Acts of Discovery : Visions of America in the Lewis and Clark Journals, p. 23

properties.Name: Lemhi Pass
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark crossed the Continental Divide, seeing the Columbia River and present-day Idaho for the first time. On Monday, August 12, 1805, Lewis sent George Drouillard out with the mission of finding which path indigenous rider's horses had taken. Lewis understood that Native Americans had inhabited the area for centuries and were therefore far more familiar with the land than the Corps of Discovery. The tracks made by Indian's horses led Lewis and his party to Lemhi Pass, which marks the Continental Divide. Ascending into the mountains, the party saw (and attempted to shoot) an animal which they thought might be a wolf or fox, but was likely a wolverine. Climbing higher into the mountains, Lewis saw a river which he assumed to be the Columbia but was probably either the Snake or Salmon Rivers. The expedition grew increasingly excited at the prospect of reaching the Pacific Ocean. Observing the tall, rugged mountains around them, Lewis and the men knew that a long, arduous journey west still remained.

properties.Name: Sacagawea Encounters Her Long-Lost Brother
properties.Synopsis: While hunting, expedition member George Drouillard encountered several Shoshone hunters. The expedition met with Shoshone tribal leaders, subsequently discovering that Shoshone Chief Cameahwait was Sacagawea's long-lost brother. As youth, they had been kidnapped by a Hidatsa raiding party together, but Cameahwait had escaped and rejoined the tribe while Sacagawea had not. Cameahwait provided the expedition with horses for an overland voyage across the Continental Divide, a journey unadvisable by water (the only alternative route). This event is significant in its reinforcement of Sacagawea's importance to the expedition’s success. Her presence greatly improved the party’s diplomatic relations with indigenous groups, particularly those with whom she maintained personal or social relationships.

properties.Name: Crossing the Bitterroot Mountains
properties.Synopsis: The Corps of Discovery found themselves in the rugged, mountainous terrain of the Bitterroot Mountains. The expedition was forced to contend with treacherous trails, lost horses, and scarce game. They frequently became lost and faced significant fatigue, hunger, and attendant low morale.

properties.Name: Weippe Prairie
properties.Synopsis: Clark made contact with the Nez Perce after emerging from the Rocky Mountains (Lolo Trail). The Nez Perce were a semi-nomadic, hunter-gatherer people who relied mostly on foraging. They were also known to be excellent fishers and were incredibly skilled in the art of boat making, a fact which would save the Expedition later on in the journey.  After Clark made contact, the rest of the Corps followed two days later.
properties.Secondary Source: Ray, Verne F. Lewis and Clark and the Nez Perce Indians. Great Western Series ; No. 10. Washington, D.C.: Potomac Corral, the Westerners, 1971.

properties.Name: Woes of a Traveler
properties.Synopsis: In what have been described at the three worst weeks of the Lewis & Clark journey, the Lewis & Clark expedition was subject to what all travelers fear: traveler's diarrhea. After successful negotiations and marvelous feasts with the Nez Perce tribe, a large percentage of the Lewis & Clark expedition was succumb debilitating diarrhea and horrendous gas pains. Poor Lewis could not even bear to ride his horse even at a gentle trot, and the expedition was slowed dramatically.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988. and Vastag B. Medicine on the Lewis and Clark Trail. JAMA. 2003;289(10):1227–1230. doi:10.1001/jama.289.10.1227

properties.Name: Canoe Camp
properties.Synopsis: Due to the illness the Expedition had succumbed to after the feast with the Nez Perce, the fate of the journey hung in the balance. With not enough men able to work, the task of building canoes to continue along the Clearwater River took a lengthy ten days to complete before the men could be on their way. The expedition (using small axes) built 5 canoes out of Ponderosa pine for the journey to the Pacific.  The Nez Perce assisted the expedition in both canoe building and accompanied them along the Clearwater River in order to be of assistance in serving as intermediaries between the explorers and the Sahaptian-speaking peoples. Without assistance from this tribe, the expedition may have ended here.

properties.Name: Clearwater River
properties.Synopsis: With many of the men finally in recovery, the expedition was able to continue. The group departed on the Clearwater River in five canoes that had been successfully built with the assistance of the Nez Perce. However, their assistance did not end there. The Corps was accompanied by two Nez Perce chiefs, Twisted Hair and Tetoharsky, who were instrumental in helping with translations on the later parts of the expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Pinkham, Allen., Evans, Steven Ross, and Hoxie, Frederick E. Lewis and Clark among the Nez Perce : Strangers in the Land of the Nimiipuu. Ron Laycock Collection of Lewis and Clark Literature. Washburn, North Dakota: Dakota Institute Press of the Lewis & Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, 2013.

properties.Name: Mount Hood Sighting
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark held a council with the local Walla Walla Indians. The expedition traded bells, knitting pins, and other items of little value for forty of the Walla Walla's dogs. This trade exemplifies the paternalism with which Lewis and Clark viewed indigenous Americans. Continuing along the banks of the Columbia River, the expedition observed tribal members catching and drying salmon. The salmon economy was integral to indigenous life and livelihood along the Snake and Columbia Rivers, as it was throughout much of the Pacific Northwest. Clark recorded seeing a conical, snow-covered mountain: this was most likely Mount Hood, one of Oregon's most iconic peaks.

properties.Name: Celilo Falls
properties.Synopsis: The expedition encountered a dangerous stretch of the Columbia that lasted through the Dalles. The rapids at Celilo Falls were an indigenous salmon fishery and the oldest continually inhabited community on the North American continent, drawing tribes from across Oregon and southern Washington. American Indians had fished Celilo Falls for ten thousand years; the falls were integral to the region's salmon economy and rich cultural life. Tribes held annual ceremonies celebrating the beginning of the yearly salmon run in the village on the Columbia's southern banks. The falls would be submerged in the 1950s, and the village inundated, following the construction of the Dalles Dam.

properties.Name: Portage over the Cascades of the Columbia
properties.Synopsis: The expedition portaged around the Cascades of the Columbia (Grand Shutes) and traveled seven miles through the Columbia River Gorge.

properties.Name: False Ocean Sighting
properties.Synopsis: Clark mistakenly claimed to have seen the Pacific Ocean, but the expedition was in fact twenty miles away.

properties.Name: Minority Vote
properties.Synopsis: Camping near McKenzie Head, Lewis and Clark had to decide where to spend the winter.  The options were to stay where they were, to cross to the southern side of the river to look for a better spot, or to return to Celilo Falls.  Lewis and Clark agreed that at the coast the whether would be less severe, and elk might be more plentiful south of the river.  But they decided to put it to a vote, including the voices of York and Sacagawea. This is the first record of a slave, a woman, and a Native American being allowed to vote on a decision pertaining to the United States. While this is a momentous occasion, it must still be acknowledged that these rights were not granted to the rest of the American population for over a century afterwards.
properties.Secondary Source: Ambrose, p. 316.

properties.Name: Fort Clatsop
properties.Synopsis: The expedition constructed Fort Clatsop on the south bank of the Columbia (per their historically inclusive vote) in order to weather the coastal winter, establishing an American presence by flying a flag over the fort.
properties.Secondary Source: Karsmizki, Kenneth W. "Cartographic Representations: A Controversy in Mapping Lewis and Clark's Fort Clatsop." Oregon Historical Quarterly 105, no. 4 (2004): 568-87.

properties.Name: Winter Obstacle
properties.Synopsis: On December 16th 1805, the expedition encountered one of the worse winter days that they were to face along their rout. Rain coupled with violent wind caused trees to be downed around them. Unequipped to deal with the weather the men often spent these days huddled for warmth on the shores of the river, unable to paddle their canoes through the treacherous waves.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988.

properties.Name: Whale
properties.Synopsis: Clark and others encountered a whale stranded on the beach to the south. When the party arrives they negotiate with the Tillamook Indians for blubber and oil.

properties.Name: Sauvie Island
properties.Synopsis: Clark explored the Willamette River while the expedition camped at Sauvie Island, making notes on local natives. Most groups residing in the Columbia's Sauvie Island region belonged to Upper-Chinookan language groups, including the Katlaminimin, Clatskanie, Cath-la-cum-up, Clâh-in-nata, Cath-lah-nah-qui-ah, and Cath-lah-cam-mah-tup. Both Lewis and Clark made extensive notes about the rich complexity of tribal cultures, such as different types of dwellings, clothing, and hairstyles. The expedition leaders also noted the extent to which indigenous peoples used natural materials—particularly native plants—to construct homes and trade with other, nearby tribes.

properties.Name: Walla Walla Indians
properties.Synopsis: Walla Walla Indians invite them to stay and provide guidance on the expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Pinkham, Allen., Evans, Steven Ross, and Hoxie, Frederick E. Lewis and Clark among the Nez Perce : Strangers in the Land of the Nimiipuu. Ron Laycock Collection of Lewis and Clark Literature. Washburn, North Dakota: Dakota Institute Press of the Lewis & Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, 2013.

properties.Name: Camp Chopunnish
properties.Synopsis: The expedition retrieved their horses from the Nez Perce and remained in Cap Chopunnish until the snows on the Rocky Mountains allowed for passage.

properties.Name: Lewis' horse slips 40 feet
properties.Synopsis: The Bitterroot Mountains are a section of the Rocky Mountains that create the border between Idaho and Montana. They were an extreme challenge to the Expedition due to their size and formidable peaks. While crossing the Bitterroots, Lewis' horse slipped and they both fell 40 feet down a mountain. Luckily, they both survived to continue the journey home.

properties.Name: Travelers' Rest
properties.Synopsis: Having finally made it through the treacherous journey crossing Bitterroots, the expedition began the final part of their trek home. The group split up to explore different routes to the Missouri river, each thinking that they could find the faster route home. Clark went up towards Yellowstone with half of the expedition and Lewis continued on the Nez Perce route with the other half.  Sergeants Ordway and Pryor were given separate tasks with smaller units.  The Corps wouldn't be reunited until they reached the Missouri several weeks later.  Lewis and Clark must have had a lot of faith in their men to delegate so much responsibility.
properties.Secondary Source: Ambrose, Stephen E. Undaunted Courage: Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West. New York: Simon & Schuster, 1996, p. 375-376.

properties.Name: Seaman's Creek
properties.Synopsis: Proceeding according to a shortcut the expedition had learned from natives, Lewis discovered a creek and named it after his steadfast companion. Donald Jackson later uses this event to determine that the dog’s name was Seaman (rather than Scannon, as had been previously thought): "No person named Seaman is known to have been associated with the lives of either captain, and as a common term the word seems strangely nautical in view of its location. When it became necessary for Lewis and Clark to name a creek, river, or other geographical feature, they were predictably direct and simple in their choices...They usually went straight to the heart of the matter and chose a sound, reasonable name for the simplest of reasons: to commemorate a member or sponsor of the expedition...It occurred to me that the name might be a garbled version of Scannon’s Creek, in honor of the faithful dog. The dog had been with Lewis on that side trip, and no geographical feature had yet been named for him during the entire expedition. I consulted microcopies of the journals held by the American Philosophical Society, half suspecting I would find that Seaman’s Creek was actually Scannon’s Creek. What I learned instead was mildly startling. The stream was named Seaman’s Creek because the dog’s name was Seaman."
properties.Secondary Source: http://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/seaman.html

properties.Name: Up the Marais
properties.Synopsis: Leaving the rest of the party behind at Great Falls with Gass, Lewis took George Drouillard and Joseph and Reuben Field to explore the upper part of the Marais River.

properties.Name: Nathaniel Pryor's First Mission
properties.Synopsis: Nathaniel Pryor set off with two privates on his first mission to the Mandan villages.  He brought horses to trade for supplies, along with a letter to Hugh Heney of the North West Company.  The letter asked for Heney's assistance in incorporating the Sioux into the planned American commercial trading system centered in St. Louis.  The letter read in part "The ardent wish of our government has ever been to conciliate the esteem and secure the friendship of all the Savage nations within their territory by the exercise of every consistent and pacific measure in her power, applying those of coercion only in the last resort...but we are also positive that she will not long suffer her citizens to be deprived of the free navigation of the Missouri by a fiew comparatively feeble bands of Savages who may be so illy advised as to refuse her proffered friendship and continue their depridation on her citizens who may in future assend or decend that river."
properties.Secondary Source: Letters of the Lewis and Clark Expedition with Related Documents 1783-1854. Edited by Donald Jackson. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1978, p. 310.

properties.Name: Down the Yellowstone
properties.Synopsis: Clark sets off down the Yellowstone River.

properties.Name: Encounter with Blackfeet
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and his party encountered a band of Piegan Blackfeet near Two Medicine River.  When the Piegan stole some rifles during the night, Reuben Field gave chase and stabbed a man named Side Hill Calf.  The Piegan then tried to take the Americans' horses.  Lewis woke up and shot one of the Blackfeet in the stomach.  Future years would see bitter conflict between the Blackfeet and American settlers, but that had more to do with upheavals in the Plains economic system than any precedent set by this particular incident.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P.  Lewis and Clark Among the Indians.  Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, pp. 238-244.

properties.Name: Lewis is shot
properties.Synopsis: While hunting elk along the northeast bank of the Missouri River, Lewis was shot accidentally by one of his own men. The expedition had paused to hunt, with Lewis and Corps member Pierre Cruzatte setting off alone. Separated by a strand of willow trees, Cruzatte mistook Lewis, dressed in brown leather, for an elk and shot him in the right thigh and buttocks. Lewis immediately suspected that Cruzatte, who had notably poor eyesight, had accidentally fired upon him. When he called Cruzatte's name and received no response, Lewis grew concerned that the group was under attack by Indians. He hurried back to the canoes and alerted the rest of the expedition to arm themselves and find Cruzatte. The men returned quickly, having seen no Indians but discovered Cruzatte in the undergrowth. While Lewis and Gass dressed Lewis's wound, Cruzatte claimed not to have heard Lewis's cries. Lewis recorded in his journals that although he did not believe Cruzatte to have intentionally fired, he suspected that Cruzatte had hidden upon realizing that he had maimed an expedition leader, frightened of the consequences he might face.

properties.Name: Reunion Point
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark are finally reunited at the Missouri river, and begin the last leg of their 8,000 mile journey together.

properties.Name: Fort Mandan (return)
properties.Synopsis:
The expedition returns to Mandan village to find their 1804 fort burned down.  They part ways with Sacagawea and Charbonneau.  Clark later regrets not remunerating Sacagawea for her work.

The expedition returned to Mandan village to find that their 1804 fort had burnt to the ground. The cause remains unknown. While Lewis and Clark had continued their westward journey, the Mandan had been locked in conflict with other local tribes, including the Sioux. The Mandan were glad to see the expedition again, and send them gifts of corn, beans, and squash. Lewis and Clark parted ways with Sacagawea and Charbonneau—fittingly, the site of their first meeting. Clark later regretted not remunerating Sacagawea for her work; without her diplomatic, translation, and navigational skills, the expedition's success would have been jeopardized. That Sacagawea assisted the Corps of Discovery so extensively was a significant accomplishment. At the age of sixteen, she crossed the country with an infant on her back and provided the expedition with crucial support. Her establishment of contacts with indigenous peoples and contributions to the expedition's natural history remain salient aspects of American history.

properties.Name: Finally Home
properties.Synopsis: After two years, four months, and ten days, the Corps finally arrives back in St. Louis with their expedition complete.
